resources.string: v3 Tour Guide App (Welcome To Rome!)
ADDRESS:\nPiazza del Colosseo, 1, 00184 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Colosseum or Coliseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is an oval amphitheatre in the centre of the city of Rome, Italy. Built of travertine, tuff, and brick-faced concrete, it is the largest amphitheatre ever built. The Colosseum was used for gladiatorial contests and various public spectacles such as mock sea battles, animal hunts, executions, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas based on Classical mythology.
ADDRESS:\nVia della Salara Vecchia, 5/6, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Roman Forum, is a rectangular forum (plaza) surrounded by the ruins of several important ancient government buildings at the center of the city of Rome. Citizens of the ancient city referred to this space, originally a marketplace, as the Forum Magnum, or simply the Forum. For centuries the Forum was the center of day-to-day life in Rome: the site of triumphal processions and elections; the venue for public speeches, criminal trials, and gladiatorial matches; and the nucleus of commercial affairs. The Forum today is a sprawling ruin of architectural fragments and intermittent archaeological excavations.
ADDRESS:\nVia di San Gregorio, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Arch of Constantine is a triumphal arch in Rome, situated between the Colosseum and the Palatine Hill. It was erected by the Roman Senate to commemorate Constantine I\'s victory over Maxentius at the Battle of Milvian Bridge in 312. Dedicated in 315, it is the largest Roman triumphal arch. The arch spans the Via triumphalis, the way taken by the emperors when they entered the city in triumph.

ABOUT:\nThe Arch of Titus is a 1st-century AD honorific arch, located on the Via Sacra, Rome, just to the south-east of the Roman Forum. It was constructed in c. AD 82 by the Emperor Domitian shortly after the death of his older brother Titus to commemorate Titus\'s victories. The arch has provided the general model for many triumphal arches erected since the 16th century - perhaps most famously it is the inspiration for the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, France.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza Santa Maria Nova, 53, 00186 Rome, Italy
HOURS:\nEveryday 8.30am to one hour before sunset

ABOUT:\nThe Palatine Hill is the centremost of the Seven Hills of Rome and is one of the most ancient parts of the city. It stands 40 metres above the Roman Forum, looking down upon it on one side, and upon the Circus Maximus on the other. From the time of Augustus Imperial palaces were built here. The hill is the etymological origin of the word palace and its cognates in other languages (Italian: palazzo, French: palais, German: Palast, etc.).
ADDRESS:\nVia del Circo Massimo, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Circus Maximus is an ancient Roman chariot-racing stadium and mass entertainment venue located in Rome, Italy. Situated in the valley between the Aventine and Palatine Hills, it was the first and largest stadium in ancient Rome and its later Empire. It measured 621 m (2,037 ft) in length and 118 m (387 ft) in width and could accommodate over 150,000 spectators. In its fully developed form, it became the model for circuses throughout the Roman Empire. The site is now a public park.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza del Campidoglio, 1, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Capitoline Museums are a single museum containing a group of art and archaeological museums in Piazza del Campidoglio, on top of the Capitoline Hill in Rome, Italy. It opened to the public in 1734 under Clement XII, the Capitoline Museums are considered the first museum in the world, understood as a place where art could be enjoyed by all and not only by the owners.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza del Campidoglio, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Capitoline Hill between the Forum and the Campus Martius, is one of the Seven Hills of Rome. The Capitolium (as it became known) was regarded by the Romans as indestructible, and was adopted as a symbol of eternity. The Capitoline Hill contains few ancient ground-level ruins, as they are almost entirely covered up by Medieval and Renaissance palaces (now housing the Capitoline Museums) that surround a piazza, a significant urban plan designed by famous sculpture, painter, architect, and poet - Michelangelo.

ABOUT:\nThe Altare della Patria (English: \"Altar of the Fatherland\"), also known as the Monumento Nazionale a Vittorio Emanuele II (\"National Monument to Victor Emmanuel II\") or Il Vittoriano, is a monument built in honor of Victor Emmanuel, the first king of a unified Italy, located in Rome, Italy. It occupies a site between the Piazza Venezia and the Capitoline Hill. The Vittoriano features stairways, Corinthian columns, fountains, an equestrian sculpture of Victor Emmanuel and two statues of the goddess Victoria riding on quadrigas. The base of the structure houses the museum of Italian Unification.
ADDRESS:\nVia dei Fori Imperiali, 00187 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nTrajan\'s Column is a Roman triumphal column in Rome, Italy, that commemorates Roman emperor Trajan\'s victory in the Dacian Wars. It is located in Trajan\'s Forum, north of the Roman Forum. Completed in AD 113, the freestanding column is most famous for its spiral bas relief, which artistically represents the wars between the Romans and Dacians (101–102 and 105–106). Its design has inspired numerous victory columns, both ancient and modern.
ADDRESS:\nVia Quattro Novembre, 94, 00187 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nTrajan\'s Market is a large complex of ruins in the city of Rome, Italy. Located on the Via dei Fori Imperiali, at the opposite end to the Colosseum. Thought to be the world\'s oldest shopping mall, the arcades in Trajan\'s Market are now believed by many to be administrative offices for Emperor Trajan. The shops and apartments were built in a multi-level structure and it is still possible to visit several of the levels. Highlights include delicate marble floors and the remains of a library.
Basilica Papale di Santa Maria Maggiore
ADDRESS:\nPiazza di S. Maria Maggiore, 42, 00100 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore or church of Santa Maria Maggiore, is a Papal major basilica and the largest Catholic Marian church in Rome, Italy. The basilica enshrines the venerated image of Salus Populi Romani, depicting the Blessed Virgin Mary as the help and protectress of the Roman people, which was granted a Canonical coronation by Pope Gregory XVI on 15 August 1838 accompanied by his Papal bull Cælestis Regina.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza di Trevi, 00187 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Trevi Fountain is a fountain in the Trevi district in Rome, Italy, designed by Italian architect Nicola Salvi and completed by Giuseppe Pannini. Standing 26.3 metres (86 ft) high and 49.15 metres (161.3 ft) wide, it is the largest Baroque fountain in the city and one of the most famous fountains in the world. The fountain has appeared in several notable films, including Federico Fellini\'s "La Dolce Vita", the eponymous \"Three Coins in the Fountain\", and \"Roman Holiday\".
ADDRESS:\nPiazza della Rotonda, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Pantheon (from the Greek: Pantheion, \"[temple] of all the gods\") is a former Roman temple, now a church, in Rome, Italy, on the site of an earlier temple commissioned by Marcus Agrippa during the reign of Augustus (27 BC - 14 AD). It was completed by the emperor Hadrian and probably dedicated around 126 AD. Its date of construction is uncertain, because Hadrian chose not to inscribe the new temple but rather to retain the inscription of Agrippa\'s older temple, which had burned down.

ABOUT:\nFontana dei Quattro Fiumi (Fountain of the Four Rivers) is a fountain in the Piazza Navona in Rome, Italy. It was designed in 1651 by Gian Lorenzo Bernini for Pope Innocent X whose family palace, the Palazzo Pamphili, faced onto the piazza as did the church of Sant\'Agnese in Agone of which Innocent was the sponsor.

ABOUT:\nPiazza Navona is a square in Rome, Italy. It is built on the site of the Stadium of Domitian, built in the 1st century AD, and follows the form of the open space of the stadium. The ancient Romans went there to watch the agones (games), and hence it was known as \"Circus Agonalis\" (\"Competition Arena\"). It is believed that over time the name changed to \"in avone\" then to \"navone\" and eventually to \"navona\".

ABOUT:\nThe Mausoleum of Hadrian, usually known as Castel Sant\'Angelo (Castle of the Holy Angel), is a towering cylindrical building in Parco Adriano, Rome, Italy. It was initially commissioned by the Roman Emperor Hadrian as a mausoleum for himself and his family. The building was later used by the popes as a fortress and castle, and is now a museum. The structure was once the tallest building in Rome.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza San Pietro, 00120 Città del Vaticano, Vatican City

ABOUT:\nSt. Peter\'s Square is a large plaza located directly in front of St. Peter\'s Basilica in the Vatican City, the papal enclave inside Rome, directly west of the neighbourhood or rione of Borgo. Both the square and the basilica are named after Saint Peter, an apostle of Jesus and the first Catholic Pope. At the centre of the square there is an ancient Egyptian obelisk, erected at the current site in 1586.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza San Pietro, 00120 Città del Vaticano, Vatican City

ABOUT:\nThe Papal Basilica of St. Peter in the Vatican or simply St. Peter\'s Basilica is an Italian Renaissance church in Vatican City, the papal enclave within the city of Rome. Designed principally by Donato Bramante, Michelangelo, Carlo Maderno and Gian Lorenzo Bernini, St. Peter\'s is the most renowned work of Renaissance architecture and the largest church in the world. While it is neither the mother church of the Catholic Church nor the cathedral of the Diocese of Rome, St. Peter\'s is regarded as one of the holiest Catholic shrines.
ADDRESS:\nCitta del Vaticano 1, 00120 Vatican City, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Sistine Chapel is a chapel in the Apostolic Palace, the official residence of the Pope, in Vatican City. Originally known as the Cappella Magna, the chapel takes its name from Pope Sixtus IV, who restored it between 1477 and 1480. Since that time, the chapel has served as a place of both religious and functionary papal activity. Today it is the site of the Papal conclave, the process by which a new pope is selected. The fame of the Sistine Chapel lies mainly in the frescos that decorate the interior, and most particularly the Sistine Chapel ceiling and The Last Judgment by Michelangelo.
HOURS:\nMonday - Saturday 9:00am - 6:00pm\nEvery Last Sunday Of The Month 9:00am - 2:00pm

ABOUT:\nThe Vatican Museums are Christian and art museums located within the city boundaries of the Vatican City. They display works from the immense collection amassed by Popes throughout the centuries including some of the most renowned classical sculptures and most important masterpieces of Renaissance art in the world. The museums contain roughly 70,000 works, of which 20,000 are on display, and currently employ 640 people who work in 40 different administrative, scholarly, and restoration departments.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza di Spagna, 00187 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Spanish Steps are a set of steps in Rome, Italy, climbing a steep slope between the Piazza di Spagna at the base and Piazza Trinità dei Monti, dominated by the Trinità dei Monti church at the top. The monumental stairway of 135 steps (the slightly elevated drainage system is often mistaken for the first step) was built with French diplomat Étienne Gueffier’s bequeathed funds of 20,000 scudi, in 1723–1725.
ADDRESS:\nPiazzale Scipione Borghese, 5, 00197 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nThe Galleria Borghese (Borghese Gallery) is an art gallery in Rome, Italy, housed in the former Villa Borghese Pinciana. At the outset, the gallery building was integrated with its gardens, but today, the Villa Borghese gardens are considered a separate tourist attraction. The Galleria Borghese houses a substantial part of the Borghese collection of paintings, sculpture and antiquities, begun by Cardinal Scipione Borghese, the nephew of Pope Paul V. The Villa was built by the architect Flaminio Ponzio, developing sketches by Scipione Borghese himself, who used it as a villa suburbana, a country villa at the edge of Rome.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza del Popolo, 00187 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\nPiazza del Popolo is a large urban square in Rome. The name in modern Italian literally means \"People\'s Square\", but historically it derives from the poplars after which the church of Santa Maria del Popolo, in the northeast corner of the piazza, takes its name. The piazza lies inside the northern gate in the Aurelian Walls, once the Porta Flaminia of ancient Rome, and now called the Porta del Popolo. This was the traveller\'s first view of Rome upon arrival. For centuries, the Piazza del Popolo was a place for public executions, the last of which took place in 1826.
ADDRESS:\nVia Degli Orti di Cesare ⅓ | Near Stazione Trastevere, 00153 Rome, Italy

HOURS:
Monday Closed
Tuesday - Thursday 12:00pm - 3:00pm and 7:00pm - 10:30pm
Friday - Sunday 12:00pm - 3:00pm and 7:00pm - 11:00pm

ABOUT:\nCasareccia cuisine in an intimate and welcoming atmosphere near Trastevere station. Staff young, friendly and helpful to your requests. Traditional Roman cuisine and other specialities await you.

ABOUT:\nThe Tamburelli specialties are unique and original dishes. The best of Campanian and Mediterranean cuisine, revisited by the aged chef Corrado Talamo, award-winning, with over 40 years of experience and some successful books to his credit, such as the encyclopedic book, \"La Storia della Cucina\", also downloadable online.

ABOUT:\nWe are in the heart of the Roman tradition, in the center of culture, at the highest density point of the capital\'s restaurants. This is why we must be head and shoulders above the rest in our sector. We offer you Roman dishes at their best, a staff at your disposal that will always welcome you with a smile and all the space of our 5 rooms at your disposal. Each ingredient is carefully selected, the presentation of our dishes is never left to chance, and our staff in the room are trained to give you the best of experiences. We do not talk about Tiramisù, you have to come and taste it.

ABOUT:\nBurger Bistrot was born in October 2017 from the idea of ​​two Roman boys with the intent to bring innovation into one of the most eaten dishes in the world. We are the first \"hamburgeria\" in Rome where you can eat a hamburger cooked in a vacuum, a process that makes it juicy and never dry.
ADDRESS:\nVia del Governo Vecchio 72, 00186 Rome, Italy

ABOUT:\nRight in the heart of Rome, there\'s a place where the sun always shines. It\'s where you can find us. Cosy and inviting, located in what was once a 16th century Bishop\'s Palace, ours is the perfect location for anyone who wants to relish an easy going and comfortable mood on the set of Rome\'s bustling nightlife. With a vas assortment of wines, a special eye to Italian ones, you can find platters of cold meats and cheese or traditional dishes such as carbonara or straccetti. You can also enjoy a Traminer with a Pizza Margherita, a fresh mixed salad and our hallmark crostini of potatoes with a choice of \"provola cheese and vegetables\" or \"speck and porcini mushrooms\"! To finish with style you can try our yummy Illy Tiramisù served warm and made on the spot for you.
ADDRESS:\nVia del Governo Vecchio 87, 00186 Rome, Italy

ABOUT:\nEating is an emotional experience. We take care to create the best atmosphere, with staff that takes care of you to make you feel at home. Our cooks and pizza makers are accustomed to a high level of attention to detail, with food cooked specifically for you. Your satisfaction is all we crave. A good meal is not just something that fills the stomach, but something pleasant that should never be forgotten.
ABOUT:\nServing a good selection of Italian, barbecue and gluten free options. It\'s a great place for local cuisine, special occasions, large groups and families with children.

ABOUT:\nAs Alchemists create gold, we transform the raw material to create healthy dishes and haute cuisine, in a quick and practical solution to be consumed on the street, at work or at home. We serve a great selection of Italian, seafood, European, healthy, street food, mediterranean, vegetarian friendly, vegan options and gluten free options.

ABOUT:\nBefore being a trattoria, Osti Matti wants to be a project to rediscover ancient flavors. Passion, love and care, this is the starting point for all great meals. Osti Matti is a great dining location for families with children, special occasions, romantic nights out and local cuisine.
ADDRESS:\nVia Leone IV 34 | Intersection with Via Giulio Cesare, 00192 Rome, Italy
ABOUT:\nFamily friendly restaurant serving Italian, brew pub, fast food, cafe, Mediterranean, European, vegetarian, vegan and gluten free options.
ADDRESS:\nVia della Pelliccia 47/53 | Trastevere, 00153 Rome, Italy
ABOUT:\nFamily friendly restaurant that also accommodates large groups. Serving a great selection of Italian, vegetarian, vegan and gluten free food choices.
ADDRESS:\nSalita dei Crescenzi, 31, 00186 Roma RM, Italy
ABOUT:\nA long-standing family friendly restaurant serving hearty, traditional Roman fare in a wood-paneled dining room. Vegetarian and gluten free options are available as well.

ABOUT:\n5 Star Hotel - Palazzo Manfredi is a magnificent historic villa that today serves as five-star hotel offering the tradition and warm hospitality of the Counts Manfredi. Every detail is a family jewel, from the spectacular view of the Colosseum, to the courtesy of our staff, the classic and contemporary elegance of the decor, and our sophisticated restaurant on one of Rome\'s most romantic terraces. History is on our doorstep, but true luxury is being part of a great family\'s history.

ABOUT:\n5 Star Hotel - Palazzo Montemartini is a 3-minute walk from the nearest metro station, this contemporary hotel in a stately former palazzo is a minute\'s stroll from the National Roman Museum\'s Baths of Diocletian. Individually decorated rooms feature hardwood floors and chic furnishings, and include flat-screen TVs, free Wi-Fi and minibars. Distinctive touches in individual suites include private spas, fitness equipment and lounges, as well as terraces with scenic city views.

ABOUT:\nIQ Hotel Roma is a 4 star hotel, with a twist! Located in downtown Rome, just a short 15 minute walk from the Trevi Fountain or the Colosseum and with Repubblica metro station just 200 metres away, hotels don\'t get much more central than this. IQ guests enjoy free Wi-Fi connection throughout the hotel, a lovely terrace to unwind while overlooking the Opera House, and free access to our gym and sauna. IQ offers very competitive prices. Now that you\'ve found us, welcome to a whole new hotel experience!

ABOUT:\n4 Star Hotel - VOI Donna Camilla Savelli is set in a converted 17th-century convent in the Trastevere district, this refined hotel lies a minute\'s walk from a bus stop, 2.4 km from the Sistine Chapel and 2.9 km from the Colosseum. Featuring tile floors, the elegant rooms include free Wi-Fi, flat-screen TVs and minibars. Room service is available. Upgraded rooms feature antique furniture, while suites add separate living areas. The hotel provides complimentary, American-style breakfast.

ABOUT:\n4 Star Hotel - The Britannia Hotel is in the centre of Rome, only 200 meters from the Teatro dell\'Opera opera house and the Repubblica metro station. An elegant nineteenth century building houses The Britannia Hotel, a refined boutique hotel with a particularly British atmosphere. These intimate and elegant chambers are equipped with top quality linen, private bathrooms with spacious showers or baths, satellite TV with LCD screens, a free high-speed Wi-Fi internet connection, a safe, an ironing board and a UV sun lamp. We also offer guests a selection of free items in the mini-bar upon arrival.

ABOUT:\n3 Star Hotel - Hotel Santa Maria was awarded the Certificate of Excellence and ranked in the top 10 hotels in Rome by TripAdvisor. The Hotel Santa Maria Rome is situated in the charming district of Trastevere. Consistently rated by guests as a fantastic hotel which offers excellent value for money. The Hotel Santa Maria is situated in a completely renovated 16th Century cloister offering 19 comfortable rooms and positioned within walking distance of the major archaeological and tourist sites of Rome.

ABOUT:\n4 Star Hotel - Cardilli Luxury Rooms is a 7-minute walk from the nearest metro stop. This intimate hotel in Rome\'s historic center lies 1.1 km from the Roman Forum and 1.3 km from the Colosseum. Refined rooms and suites with soundproof windows, private bathrooms, free Wi-Fi, TVs and minibars. Suites add separate sitting areas. Room service is offered. Free breakfast is served in an elegant dining room. Pets are welcome.
ADDRESS:\nVia San Giuseppe Calasanzio 1, 00186 Rome, Italy

ABOUT:\n4 Star Hotel - Martis Palace Hotel Rome is in a stately neoclassical building surrounded by shops and eateries. This polished hotel is a 3-minute walk from Piazza Navona, a landmark square with fountains, and 3 km from Termini train station. Warmly furnished rooms have free Wi-Fi and flat-screen TVs, as well as minibars and laptop-sized safes. Elegant suites add sitting areas; some include 4-poster beds. Other amenities include a rooftop terrace and a sophisticated guest lounge.
ADDRESS:\nVia di Campo Marzio 52/a, Rome, Italy

ABOUT:\n4 Star Hotel - Campo Marzio Luxury Suites is in an historic building on a cobblestone street. This polished hotel is an 8-minute walk from both the Trevi Fountain and Piazza Navona. It\'s 2 km from Roma Termini train station. Warm, understated rooms and suites come with complimentary Wi-Fi, flat-screen TVs and minibars; some add exposed brick walls. An upgraded suite has a sitting area and a free-standing tub. In-room continental breakfast is included.Parking is offered for a fee.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza Campo de\' Fiori, 27, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\n4 Star Hotel - Mama\'s Home Rome overlooks the Campo de\' Fiori square. This upscale all-suite hotel in a 14th-century home is an 8-minute walk from the ancient Pantheon temple, 1 km from the 2nd-century Castel Sant\'Angelo and 2 km from the Colosseum. Chic suites with sleek decor and wood ceiling beams have free Wi-Fi, flat-screen TVs and Nespresso machines; some feature in-room, claw-foot tubs. Upgraded suites offer views of the square. Bike rentals are available, as is chauffeur service from the airport or train station for a fee.

ABOUT:\n4 Star Hotel - Rome Life Hotel is a chic downtown hotel with a wooden facade. It\'s an 8-minute walk from a metro stop and 1.3 km from the Colosseum. The upscale, modern rooms include free Wi-Fi, 107-cm flat-screen HDTVs with satellite channels, minibars, and tea and coffeemakers. The hotel serves a complimentary breakfast buffet in a contemporary dining room. There\'s a similarly styled bar and a 24/7 front desk.
The Inn at the Roman Forum
ADDRESS:\nVia degli Ibernesi, 30, 00184 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\n5 Star Hotel - The Inn at the Roman Forum is a 4-minute walk from the bus station, this upscale urban hotel with Roman ruins and an annex is also 12 minutes from the Colosseum. The plush, elegant rooms offer free Wi-Fi, flat-screen TVs and iPod docks, plus minibars. Upgraded rooms have Jacuzzis. Some have fireplaces or sitting areas, and suites including sitting rooms. Upgraded suites have patios with rooftop access. Other amenities include a business center, a lounge with a fireplace, and an ancient crypt with 2000-year-old stone engravings.

ABOUT:\n5 Star Hotel - Hotel Raphaël is a 2-minute walk from the 1st-century Piazza Navona and the bus station. This sophisticated, ivy-covered hotel is a 14-minute walk from the famous Trevi Fountain. The warmly decorated, upscale rooms offer free Wi-Fi, flat-screen TVs and minibars. Some of the upgraded rooms have terraces, and elegant suites include living rooms. Some have private balconies. There\'s a refined restaurant with seasonal outdoor seating, plus an on-site museum and an art gallery.
ADDRESS:\nPiazza dei Cinquecento, 90, 00185 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\n5 Star Hotel - NH Collection Roma Palazzo Cinquecento overlooks Piazza dei Cinquecento and adjacent to Roma Termini train station. This upmarket hotel fronted by a garden with Roman ruins is 2 km from the Colosseum. The contemporary rooms come with free Wi-Fi and flat-screen TVs, plus minibars, espresso machines and rainfall showers. Upgraded quarters provide sitting areas and/or terraces, while suites offer separate living areas with sofabeds.
ADDRESS:\nVicolo di S. Nicola de\' Cesarini, 2, 00148 Roma RM, Italy

ABOUT:\n5 Star Hotel - Pantheon Caesar Relais is on a cobbled street opposite the Largo di Torre Argentina archaeological site. This relaxed bed-and-breakfast is a 5-minute walk from the iconic Pantheon church, a 9-minute walk from Piazza Navona square and 3 km from Roma Termini train station. The 5 straightforward rooms provide complimentary Wi-Fi, flat-screen TVs and minifridges, plus tea and coffeemakers; most offer Largo di Torre Argentina views. Distinctive features in individual rooms include a balcony and a sitting area. Continental breakfast is served in-room.
Walk On Walk Off: Flexible Rome Tour Pass

ABOUT:\nUnlock Rome with a flexible tour pass allowing you to take tours on your own schedule. Choose from 10 different tours, from relaxed city strolls, to deep dives into history and even a food tour. Don\'t worry about reserving in advance. Just show up 10 minutes before a tour starts and walk on. If your plans change, it\'s not a problem, the tour runs with or without you.
Top Tier Colosseum Tour with Special Access to 3rd, 4th and 5th Levels, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill

ABOUT:\nStep up into the 3rd, 4th and 5th tiers of the Colosseum for spectacular views. Enjoy a full general-access Colosseum tour with an expert guide. Immerse yourself in the daily life of ancient Romans in the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill.
Rome In A Day Tour: Including Vatican, Colosseum and Historic Center
DURATION:\n7 hours 30 minutes (1 hour 15 minute break)

ABOUT:\nRome wasn\'t built in a day, but with our tour, you can see it in a day! You will see all the top sights of Rome including the Vatican Museums, Colosseum and historic center (Pantheon, Trevi Fountain and Piazza Navona). Also includes a self-guided visit to St. Peter\'s Basilica. With a private transfer from the historic center to the Vatican, we\'ve taken care of all the details for a fun, hassle-free day. Enjoy skip the line entrance at all the sites you visit (Vatican, Colosseum, St Peter\'s Basilica).
Pompeii Tour from Rome with Amalfi Coast Drive

ABOUT:\nExplore incredible archaeological sites at Pompeii with an expert guide. Relax and enjoy a drive along the Amalfi Coast with a stop at Positano town. Round-trip transport and a friendly English-speaking tour leader make this a fun and hassle free tour.
Crypts, Bones and Catacombs: An Underground Tour of Rome

ABOUT:\nVisit the quietest and most impressive of Rome\'s Catacombs in a small group - so you can hear your guide! See it for yourself: The eerie \"Bone Chapel\", covered in the bones of 4,000 friars. Discover just how deep the history of Rome goes at a multi-layered (multi-purpose!) Ancient Roman temple/prison/Basilica.
Rome Ghost and Mystery Night Walking Tour

ABOUT:\nAs the sun sets over Rome a new city comes to light – a city of legends and mystery, where thousands of years have left a story behind every stone. The stories Rome has to tell are far from the average bedtime tale, fraught with murder, execution and haunting. Join our expert, English-speaking storytellers who will tell you about the unseen history behind the stunning buildings of central Rome. You\’ll see the house of the most notorious (and empathetic) murderer ever to work in the Eternal City and how Rome cured its crime problems by hanging pictures of the Virgin Mary on every corner. and visit the bridge that legend has it, is haunted by the ghost of the female Pope.
VIP Colosseum Underground Tour with Roman Forum and Palatine Hill

ABOUT:\nGo where few tourists have gone before with this VIP Colosseum Underground tour, taking you to closed areas of the Colosseum so you can truly experience the magic of Ancient Rome. Visit the Colosseum underground and walk on the arena floor. Enjoy a full tour of the general access areas of the Colosseum, Roman Forum and Palatine Hill.
Skip the Line: Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel and St Peter\'s Basilica Half-Day Walking Tour

ABOUT:\nDiscover Vatican City with a guide and skip-the-line access, including the Vatican Museums, St Peter\’s Basilica and the Sistine Chapel. Home to the world\’s largest private portfolio of artwork, the Vatican is a must-see for visitors to Rome, and the best way to explore it is with a guide. Learn about Raphael\’s Rooms, the Michelangelo frescoes of the Sistine Chapel, the "La Pietà" sculpture in St Peter\’s Basilica and more. Choose from several start times or upgrade to a small-group tour with just 12 people.\n *The entrance fee (not included) is payable on the day of your tour.
Colosseum and Ancient Rome Tour by Night

ABOUT:\nTour the amphitheater and other sites of Ancient Rome under the atmospheric cover of darkness during this 2.5-hour evening tour. Learn about the ruins of the Roman Forum seen from the Piazza del Campidoglio, and enter the Colosseum after the daytime crowds have disappeared and the temperature has dropped. Visit the arena\’s underground chambers, which are closed to most of the public, and stand where gladiators once stood centuries ago. This tour is limited to 25 people.
Roman Gladiator School: Learn How to Become a Gladiator

ABOUT:\nFind out what it takes to be an ancient Roman gladiator at the Gladiator School of Rome. During a hands-on lesson with instructors from the Historic Group of Rome, learn how to fight with authentic weapons of the time while wearing a traditional gladiator tunic and belt. Located on the Appian Way, not far from the Colosseum, this class is a unique and interactive way to learn about ancient Roman history, sports, and culture.\n *Select a lesson time when booking.
